intro: Kearnemalvastrum subtriflorum, commonly known as the three-flowered mallows, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its showy, pink or purple flowers that bloom in clusters of three, giving it its common name. Its leaves are palmately lobed and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks.
